summary: This is an email chain from July 2021 between a U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) Task Force Officer and a U.S. Attorney's Office regarding travel records for Ghislaine Maxwell and Jeffrey Epstein. The CBP officer confirms the provided TECS travel records are complete for the period 1990-2000 and offers additional records post-2000, attaching a spreadsheet of Maxwell's travel crossings.

persons.name: Raymond Sanicolaia
persons.role: U.S. Customs and Border Protection Task Force Officer - SDNY US Attorney's Office
persons.context: The sender of the main email, providing analysis and travel records for Ghislaine Maxwell and Jeffrey Epstein to the U.S. Attorney's Office.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Her international travel crossings are the subject of the CBP records request and analysis. The email notes her name appears with two variations (with and without a space in her surname).

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: His international travel records are also requested and discussed alongside Maxwell's by the U.S. Attorney's Office.

connections.description: Both are subjects of a joint travel records request from the U.S. Attorney's Office, indicating their travel is being investigated together in the same case.
Sanicolaia, a CBP Task Force Officer, is providing and analyzing Maxwell's travel records for the U.S. Attorney's Office investigation.
Sanicolaia is also providing and analyzing Epstein's travel records as part of the same investigative request.

events.title: CBP Travel Records Gap
events.description: The CBP officer states that outbound travel records for individuals like Maxwell and Epstein were not systematically recorded in the CBP database during this period, limiting the available data.

events.title: Travel Records Request
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office sends travel records for Maxwell and Epstein to a CBP officer for review and requests a phone call to discuss.

events.title: CBP Analysis Provided
events.description: CBP Task Force Officer Raymond Sanicolaia responds with analysis, confirming the provided TECS records are complete for 1990-2000 and attaching a consolidated spreadsheet of Maxwell's travel crossings.

locations: U.S. Attorney's Office Southern District of New York
keyFacts: U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) confirmed that outbound travel records for individuals like Ghislaine Maxwell and Jeffrey Epstein were not systematically recorded in their database between 1990 and 2000.
The TECS travel records provided for Maxwell and Epstein represented the complete set of travel crossings recorded in CBP holdings for that date range.
Ghislaine Maxwell's name appeared in CBP records with two variations: with and without a space in her surname, resulting in two separate TECS records being provided.
A CBP Task Force Officer attached a consolidated Excel spreadsheet of Maxwell's full travel crossings in chronological order to assist the U.S. Attorney's Office investigation.
The correspondence is marked as Law Enforcement Sensitive/For Official Use Only, indicating the sensitive nature of the ongoing investigation into Maxwell and Epstein's travel.
